author: aftunion
title: El movimiento obrero latino demuestra su poder | Federación Americana de Maestros
text:
La AFT estuvo “presente” en la convención del Consejo Laboral para el Avance de América Latina del 28 de julio al 2 de agosto en Atlanta, con Evelyn DeJesus, presidenta de LCLAA y vicepresidenta ejecutiva de la AFT, inyectando su entusiasmo y energía característicos, y la presidenta de la AFT, Randi Weingarten, inspirando a los participantes a organizarse, construir poder y mantenerse fuertes frente a las amenazas a la democracia y los derechos de los inmigrantes.
Reconociendo que nuestros derechos están en peligro y que nuestra propia dignidad está siendo cuestionada, DeJesus aseguró a los asistentes que, si nos unimos, superaremos los ataques. "Lo que no entienden es esto", dijo. "Cuando vienen por uno de nosotros, vienen por todos nosotros; y aquí estamos, juntos".
Mientras la administración Trump está "desapareciendo gente", dijo Weingarten —en referencia a los agentes enmascarados del Servicio de Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE) que secuestran a personas en las calles—, también intenta dividirnos enfrentando a los inmigrantes contra quienes no lo son. Y el presidente Donald Trump y sus aliados atacan la educación, los sindicatos y los activistas porque "el conocimiento es poder, al igual que la movilización y la organización lo son", afirmó. Mantenernos fuertes, unidos, es clave.
Permanecemos unidos
La alianza de la AFT con LCLAA se basa en décadas de defensa, organización y acción conjunta. La convención de este año, con el tema "Unidos nos mantenemos: Construyendo Puentes, Rompiendo Barreras y Protegiendo Nuestro Legado", reflejó nuestro compromiso compartido, que se mantiene firme incluso en el panorama actual de deportaciones masivas y amenazas a la diversidad, la equidad y la inclusión.
A pesar del miedo palpable en la comunidad latina —un miedo que afecta personalmente a muchos de los asistentes a la conferencia—, el enfoque de LCLAA sigue siendo luchar por el futuro: unirse para afrontar el momento, tender puentes, derribar barreras y proteger el legado latino. Más específicamente, la conferencia transmitió un profundo compromiso con la defensa de los derechos de los trabajadores, la protección de las comunidades inmigrantes, el avance de la equidad y la justicia, y el empoderamiento del liderazgo latino.
“Construir puentes significa conectarnos entre nosotros, a través de generaciones, movimientos, sindicatos, comunidades, a través de todas las líneas que han intentado usar para dividirnos”, dijo DeJesus. “Significa forjar lazos profundos e inquebrantables con nuestros aliados laborales, con organizaciones de derechos civiles, con las comunidades inmigrantes, con cada hermana, hermano y hermana que cree en la justicia”.
Durante la conferencia, LCLAA dio la bienvenida a tres nuevas escuelas charter en Arizona, Kentucky y Minnesota, lo que indica un sólido crecimiento de la comunidad laboral latina. Los talleres brindaron a los participantes nuevas estrategias para el éxito, incluyendo una sesión sobre educación profesional y técnica impartida por DeJesus, una sesión sobre logros sindicales y coaliciones comunitarias impartida por la presidenta del Sindicato de Maestros de Chicago, Stacy Davis Gates, y una sesión plenaria centrada en el activismo juvenil y la organización multigeneracional en la lucha por la justicia.
Luchando hacia adelante
Los miembros de la AFT también estuvieron al frente y en el centro durante los proyectos de servicio comunitario: ayudaron a construir seis Pequeñas Bibliotecas Gratuitas y a abastecerlas con libros del proyecto La Lectura Abre el Mundo de la AFT; pintaron el pavimento del patio de juegos de una escuela primaria con juegos infantiles; y se asociaron con El Refugio, una organización de derechos de los inmigrantes, para armar mochilas llenas de artículos de tocador esenciales para los deportados recluidos en el Centro de Detención Stewart al sur de Atlanta.
La AFT también fue instrumental en la aprobación de varias resoluciones de la LCLAA, incluidas declaraciones sobre la solidaridad con los manifestantes del campus y el derecho a la libertad de expresión, la crisis de personal en la atención médica, la carta de derechos de los paraprofesionales y el personal relacionado con la escuela, la defensa del derecho de todos los niños a aprender en escuelas públicas, la defensa de los trabajadores del sector público y el derecho a aprender libre de la amenaza de deportación.
Weingarten instó a los asistentes a hacer más que simplemente contraatacar, sino también a dar un paso hacia la lucha. "Tenemos que imaginar un futuro que incluya a todos, una vida mejor para los trabajadores", dijo Weingarten, y debemos luchar por ello en la mesa de negociaciones, en las calles, en las reuniones de las juntas escolares locales y en el capitolio estatal. "Tenemos que luchar por ese futuro mejor mientras contraatacamos", dijo. "Tenemos que dar esperanza a la gente".
Otros representantes de la AFT en la LCLAA fueron los vicepresidentes de la AFT, J. Philippe Abraham, secretario del Sindicato de Maestros del Estado de Nueva York; Víctor Bonilla, presidente de la Asociación de Maestros de Puerto Rico; Kathy Chávez, presidenta de la Asociación de Asistentes Educativos de Albuquerque; y Juan Ramírez, vicepresidente ejecutivo de la CFT, la filial de la AFT en California. Bonilla, Chávez, Ramírez y el miembro del personal directivo César Moreno Pérez también forman parte de la junta ejecutiva nacional de la LCLAA.
[Virginia Myers]

text: Muslims rebuke abusive video Barbados’ Muslim community has issued a stern reproach in response to a viral video showing derogatory remarks being hurled at some of their members by individuals who appear to be visitors to the island. The incident, which allegedly occurred on the premises of the Crane Hotel, has drawn the ire of the Barbados Muslim Association, whose president, Anwar Nana, is calling on the owner of the St Philip hotel to condemn the action. In the video, a person with a foreign accent can be heard saying, “Here comes the Islamist invasion, pretending to be human,” in reference to the family, some of whom were wearing “Free Palestine” T-shirts. Nana told the Weekend Nation that a strong message needed to be sent that such acts of intolerance would not be allowed in Barbados. author: none@none.com (AFP)
title: UN ‘appalled’ by killing of 50 people in Mali attacks
text: GENEVA: The UN rights chief said Thursday he was “appalled” by alleged summary executions of 25 people by Mali’s army and “foreign military personnel” last week in a region plagued by jihadist insurgency. Volker Turk also expressed alarm at the killing of around 30 others in attacks at the weekend in central Mali, a particular hotbed of violence. “I am appalled by credible allegations that Malian armed forces accompanied by foreign military personnel summarily executed at least 25 people in Welingara village, in the central Nara region on 26 January,” Turk said in a statement. “I am also alarmed by reports that about 30 civilians were killed in attacks by yet unidentified gunmen on two other villages — Ogota and Oimbe — in the Bandiagara region over this past weekend,” he added. Gathering and verifying information in Mali is made difficult by the country’s vast geography, detriorating communications and security concerns. Jihadist violence that started in northern Mali in 2012 spread to the centre of the country in 2015, when Katiba Macina — an Al Qaeda-affiliated group — was established, led by the Fulani preacher Amadou Kouffa. Mali is led by a junta that seized power in 2020 and turned away from former colonial power France, before pushing the UN stabilisation mission MINUSMA to leave at the end of 2023. The junta has chosen instead to pivot towards Russia, both politically and militarily. Many observers claim it has enlisted the services of Russian mercenaries, despite constant denials. The UN and local sources regularly accuse the Malian army and its allies of abuses against civilians, which they systematically deny. UN rights investigators say Malian troops and foreign forces — presumed to be Wagner — were behind the massacre of at least 500 people in the central Malian town of Moura in March 2022. “It is essential that all allegations of arbitrary deprivations of life, including summary executions, are fully and impartially investigated and those found responsible brought to justice in trials observing international standards,” the UN rights chief said Thursday. author: time news
title: Floods in Germany – maps show warnings and water levels
text: 2023-12-29 15:52:00 The flood situation in parts of Germany remains tense. A key question is how much rain falls. The maps linked here show the water levels. The flood situation, especially in Lower Saxony, remains critical after days of continuous rain. “We have a very, very tense situation,” said the state’s Interior Minister, Daniela Behrens (SPD), on Deutschlandfunk on Friday. Almost all of Lower Saxony is under water. The approximately 100,000 personnel from, among others, the fire brigade and the Technical Relief Agency (THW) are deployed everywhere. The situation is also still tense in North Rhine-Westphalia. There is also a threat of new rain There is “really no relaxation in sight yet,” added Behrens. According to the weather forecast, there will be more rain and a storm in the next few days. That doesn’t ease the situation, but rather “exacerbates it in one place or another.” Due to flooding – New Year’s Eve fireworks are prohibited According to the administration, the flood situation was “still tense” in the Lower Saxony community of Lilienthal, for example. The city administration there banned the setting off of fireworks on New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Eve with the help of a general decree – in order to protect the emergency services from additional operations. According to the fire department, the situation in the town of Flotwedel in the Lower Saxony district of Celle was also “still critical”. The flood operation is continuing, it was said. On Thursday evening, residents of individual streets were evacuated and mobile dike systems were also set up. Those: [Cross-border flood portal](https://www.hochwasserzentralen.de/warnungen)as of December 29, 2023, 2:58 p.m., no data for NRW The map of [Cross-state flood portal ](https://www.hochwasserzentralen.de/warnungen)shows where flooding is expected today. In the areas marked red there is an official warning for major floods; in regions marked orange there is a conventional flood warning. In the dashed areas there is an advance warning from the responsible authorities. You can breathe deeply in green regions. An all-clear could be issued here. There is no warning in white areas. No data can currently be collected for North Rhine-Westphalia. In Meppen in Emsland, dikes were also reinforced during the night: around 400 emergency services built mobile dikes there. The local administration said there is still a risk of flooding due to the weakening of the dikes. However, the situation has stabilized. In Oldenburg, the fire department reported “a slight drop in water levels” – although more rain is expected in the coming days. It was said that a dike had not yet broken. However, in the Sandkrug district of Hatten in the Oldenburg district, the dikes continued to be reinforced, and a Bundeswehr helicopter was also scheduled to be deployed on Friday. The Hanover police reported a canoe missing with two people. This was discovered in the flood area of the River Leine, but was then no longer seen. The fire department initiated a search, but so far it has not been successful. In North Rhine-Westphalia the situation is calming down a little In North Rhine-Westphalia, the situation has temporarily eased somewhat – but according to the Environment Ministry, it is “at a high level”. Almost half of the levels are still within the warning levels. Very high levels continued to be measured on the Weser in East Westphalia. The Ministry of the Environment there has not yet given the all-clear for the most populous federal state. “We still have a major flood situation,” said NRW Environment Minister Oliver Krischer (Greens) on Friday in Düsseldorf. So far the consequences have remained manageable and there have been no casualties. There is no risk of dam failure at the dams, nor an uncontrolled overflow. The flood protection systems would have held. Levels in Dresden remain below the six meter mark In eastern Germany, many fire brigades were still in constant operation on Friday. At least there was some good news from Dresden. In the Saxon state capital, the Elbe remained below the expected six meter water level. Two meters is normal. The water level of the Elbe has been falling again since Friday night, according to data from the state flood center. The Elbe briefly reached a level of 5.95 meters. Dresden’s environmental mayor Eva Jähnigen (Greens) explained on Deutschlandfunk this morning that alert level 3 should be reduced over the course of Friday. All protective measures have been effective and there has been no major damage so far. In the north of Thuringia, a dike on the Helme River was opened in a controlled manner to avert the risk of flooding on the state border between Thuringia and Saxony-Anhalt. The Kyffhäuserkreis district announced on Friday night that the water was now flowing into fields. The opening was necessary because water had been specifically drained from the overloaded Kelbra reservoir for several days and the helmets were therefore carrying a lot of water. The highest flood alert level 4 has been in effect for the Helmets for two days. According to the district, firefighters have laid around 6,000 sandbags since Thursday to protect the small town of Mönchpfiffel-Nikolausrieth and to raise the dikes. [READ Also: More than 100 migrants have lost their lives so far in 2023 due to a heat wave on the border](https://www.time.news/more-than-100-migrants-have-lost-their-lives-so-far-in-2023-due-to-a-heat-wave-on-the-border/) The situation in the town of 300 residents eased on Friday. The water from the helmets is draining “as planned,” said a spokesman for the Kyffhäuserkreis district office. But there is still no complete all-clear. The water level in the helmets is constantly monitored and a district crisis team is still in action. The Pretzien weir near Magdeburg and Schönebeck in Saxony-Anhalt was opened on Thursday. This means that around a third of the Elbe’s water is channeled past the two cities through a flood canal and over meadows and fields before flowing back into the Elbe. text:

IGHDS organises worksop on climate change for old farmers of Sindh Our Staff Reporter November 08, 2024 Newspaper , Regional , Karachi Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share on Facebook Share on Twitter SUKKUR - Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Inter Global Human Development Society (IGHDS), Advocate Jameel Ahmed Shakeel has said that Climate change poses a significant threat to older people. He was speaking at the day-long workshop, titled “Climate Change and Older Farmers of Sindh”, said a release on Thursday.
He said that climate change directly or indirectly affects all human beings, adding that the national climate strategies must take into account the capabilities, rights and vulnerabilities of older people. Full participation of people of all ages in these strategies is essential to make them successful, he said. At present, he said that there are 11 million old people in Pakistan and the number will increase in the next 20 to 25 years. Most of them face health issues since we lack good health facilities in the country, said the CEO IGHDS.
Current year so many people lost their lives across northern Sindh including Karachi and Hyderabad due to heatwave and most of the victims were elderly people. Speaking about IGHDS, Chief Coordination Officer Nosheen Jameel Khan said that it works to provide a respectable life to the old people. Government officials and employees of some other institutions get pensions after retirement. However, labourers and farmers do not get any such benefits, he said.

Bakhtawar Nazir said that global warming started back in the 1880s, but it has gained momentum since 1950 onwards, she said. Natural disasters including, floods, hurricanes, tsunamis, thunderstorms, earthquakes, and heat waves are increasing with climate change.

title: Molly-Mae gives sad update on Bambi following Tommy Fury split in first video since breakup
text: Molly-Mae Hague has shared a sad update about daughter Bambi, following the shock news of her split from fiancé Tommy Fury. Earlier this month, [Molly-Mae](https://www.tyla.com/molly-mae-hague), 25, confirmed that [things had ‘come to an end’](https://www.tyla.com/entertainment/celebrity/molly-mae-tommy-fury-broken-up-896355-20240814), saying she felt 'extremely upset'. "After five years of being together I never imagined our story would end, especially not this way,” she told fans. Advert Since then, she’s remained fairly quiet on her platforms, apart from a [brief message on Instagram](https://www.tyla.com/entertainment/celebrity/molly-mae-breaks-social-media-silence-statement-463591-20240827) to thank followers for their support. Molly-Mae’s now shared a vlog to her YouTube channel to go into more detail about how she’s been, although [she warned that she wouldn’t be speaking about the breakup](https://www.tyla.com/entertainment/celebrity/molly-mae-tommy-fury-split-first-video-061373-20240829) specifically. She said: "That was never something that was going to happen and it's not something I ever plan on doing, or talking about. Advert "The last two weeks have been very, very real. It's real life, it's something we've been going through as privately as we can but obviously not privately whatsoever because I haven't really been able to get away from it the last couple weeks. "The last thing I want to do is come on here and fuel that more and just talk about it really. It's not my coping mechanism. "My coping mechanism is talking to the people I love, who are so close to me and have been so incredible through this time." While Molly-Mae did not wish to ‘stir the pot’ by discussing the past couple of weeks, she did allude to aspects of the breakup - including its impact on [Bambi](https://www.tyla.com/celebrity/meaning-behind-molly-mae-baby-girl-name-bambi-714659-20230201). Advert “Me and that [baby](https://www.tyla.com/parenting) have literally been joint at the hip,” she said. “We actually had a really nice couple of weeks together. I feel so, incredibly close to her at the minute, and she’s - quite frankly - obsessed with me! It’s scary. I literally can’t go to the toilet or leave the room or do anything without her crying her eyes out, which is not really ideal." Molly-Mae continued: “I think she is actually having a little bit of attachment issues at the minute. I think she can definitely sense that obviously there’s changes, and things are strange at the minute. I can really feel that she can sense that, which is very interesting considering she’s just a baby - to me, she’s just a baby; she’s not even two yet. Advert “And I feel like they’re just not stupid, they can really pick up on things.” Showing a suspiciously wet patch on the sofa to the camera, she added: “I also think that she has weed on the sofa this morning! “Just when I started filming this morning, I looked down and there’s a big wet patch in front of me, literally where she was sitting. She was wearing a nappy, so I’m not quite sure how that’s happened.” It seems the mum life never stops, even when you’ve got to share one of your career’s most highly anticipated vlogs...
